passage_text: A term of contract law to distinguish advertisements or merchandise displays from formal contract offers. An offer exposes the offeror to a contract if it is accepted by the offeree; an invitation to treat does not.

Report Abuse. In contract law, an invitation to treat (invitation to bargain in the US) is an action by one party which may appear to be a contractual offer but which is actually inviting others to make an offer of their own.

Contract law: invitations to treat (1). An invitation to treat is an invitation for customers to submit an offer, and indicates a willingness to deal. This short quiz trains the vocabulary of invitations to treat. Please purchase the course before starting the lesson.

Invitation to treat. Invitation to treat is a contract law term. It comes from the Latin phrase invitatio ad offerendum and means inviting an offer. Or as Andrew Burrows writes, an invitation to treat is an expression of willingness to negotiate.

In contract law, an invitation to treat (invitation to bargain in the US) is an action by one party which may appear to be a contractual offer but which is actually inviting others to make an offer of their own.
